title: Statistics for trees planted as substitutes for the thousands of street trees felled in Sheffield between July 2012 & August 2023

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
NOTE:
When responding to this request, PLEASE DO NOT REPOST THE FOI REQUEST AS PART OF YOUR RESPONSE; JUST POST YOUR RESPONSE. Ditto for all subsequent communications on Whatdotheyknow.com.
QUESTION/REQUEST 1:
How many highway trees have been planted in Sheffield since the ‘Streets Ahead’ project began, in 2012?
QUESTION/REQUEST 2:
How many highway trees have been planted in Sheffield since the contractual quota, to fell 17,500 street trees, was officially ditched, on the 13th of January 2023?
https://democracy.sheffield.gov.uk/ieDec...
https://ianswalkonthewildside.wordpress....
QUESTION/REQUEST 3:
British Standard - PART 1 (1992) defines seven ‘forms’ (types) of ‘Standard Trees’, as follows:
Half;
Extra Light;
Light;
Standard;
Selected;
Heavy;
Extra Heavy.
How many highway trees of each British Standard ‘form’ of ‘Standard Tree’ have been planted on Sheffield’s streets since the ‘Streets Ahead’ project began in 2012?
QUESTION/REQUEST 4:
How many of the highway trees of each British Standard ‘form’ of ‘Standard Tree’ that have been planted on Sheffield’s streets since the ‘Streets Ahead’ project began are currently on Sheffield’s streets and alive?
QUESTION/REQUEST 5:
Of the highway trees planted in Sheffield since the start of the ‘Streets Ahead’ project, in 2012, how many were lifted in to position on Sheffield’s streets using lifting machinery, such as a crane?
*****
BACKGROUND INFORMATION – the reasons for this submission:
1)
On Wednesday the 25th of April 2018, SHEFFIELD TELEGRAPH reported the following:
“Living tributes to the city's war dead are to be planted by the council at 36 sites - including all of Sheffield's major city and district parks…
THE PROJECT, WHICH REPRESENTS THE LARGEST SINGLE PLANTING OF HEAVY STANDARD TREES THE COUNCIL HAS EVER UNDERTAKEN, includes the creation of long, leafy avenues at five parks - Firth Park, Longley, Greenhill, Herdings and the Cholera Monument grounds. A single English oak will be positioned at 31 locations…”
SOURCE:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/i...
2)
The size and form of nursery stock supplied for planting is defined in Table 1 of BRITISH STANDARD 3936 - PART 1 (1992): 'Nursery stock. Specification for trees and shrubs'. See:
https://web.archive.org/web/202008111203...
3)
On the 12th of November 2012, STEVE ROBINSON – the Sheffield City Council (SCC) Head of Highway Maintenance (responsible for the £2.2bn city-wide ‘Streets Ahead’ highway maintenance project) and GRAEME SYMONDS – Network Director for Amey (the contractor acting as service provider for the project) met with Transition Sheffield. They discussed what was going to happen to Sheffield’s street trees, as part of the £2.2bn ‘Streets Ahead’ project. The minutes state that Messrs Robinson & Symonds informed:
“IT IS LIKELY THAT UP TO 50% WILL BE REPLACED over the 25 years of the contract, with about 1000 PER YEAR FOR THE FIRST 5 YEARS.
The aim is not to denude the city of trees. REPLACEMENT WILL BE WITH SEMI-MATURE TREES WHICH REQUIRE CRANING INTO POSITION, thus speeding up growth and minimising the opportunity for vandalism.”
SOURCE:
https://web.archive.org/web/201911040009...
https://www.transitionsheffield.org.uk.a...
4)
Item 3 in the ‘HIGHWAY TREE REPLACEMENT POLICY’, contained within the Streets Ahead contract (Schedule 29 – Authority Policies [PDF, 24.5MB] – pages 36 to 71), states:
“ALL REPLACEMENT TREES WILL BE containerised in 45 or 80 litre pots WITH A GIRTH BETWEEN 12 AND 16 cm. All new plants should be suitably supported until they are sufficiently established and able to stand up un-supported during strong winds.”
SOURCE:
https://www.sheffield.gov.uk/sites/defau...
https://ianswalkonthewildside.wordpress....
5)
On 27th of February 2016, DAVID CAULFIELD (then responsible for the Streets Ahead felling programme, as the SCC SCC Director of Development Services – ‘Place’) signed a witness statement, and submitted it to the High Court (Case No. CO/613/2016). To quote from paragraph 51 of the witness statement: “THE REPLACEMENT TREES ARE EXTRA HEAVY STANDARD, around 8-10 years old and around 14 to 16 cm girth and 3 metres tall depending on species.”
SOURCE:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/t...
6)
In July 2018, Ms Celia Pinnington submitted a Freedom of Information request to SCC, about the aftercare of street trees. She asked: “Are the requirements of Sheffield City Council’s Highway Tree Spacifications section 2.7.3 being adhered to?”:
https://www.sheffield.gov.uk/sites/defau...
(PDF page 51)
https://ianswalkonthewildside.wordpress....
The SCC response:
“We can confirm that this is not a contractual document and is for guidance only, appertaining primarily to semi-mature and mature trees planted for instant impact on landscaping schemes, rather than the smaller, EXTRA HEAVY STANDARDS PLANTED WITHIN THE STREETS AHEAD WORKS.”
SOURCE (Sheffield Tree Action Groups Facebook – contribution by Ms Pinnington, dated 29th July 2018):
https://web.archive.org/web/202308012211...
https://ianswalkonthewildside.wordpress....
Yours faithfully,
Mr Long

Dear Mr Long,
Thank you for your request for information relating to tree planting which
we received on 02/08/2023.
Please find Sheffield City Council’s response to your request set out
below:
1. How many highway trees have been planted in Sheffield since the
‘Streets Ahead’ project began, in 2012? (Aug 2012 to Aug 2023)
7945, this is the total number of trees planted on the highway as part of
the StreetsAhead project since 2012 to date (11-9-2023).
This number will include trees that subsequent to planting have died or
have been vandalised were subsequently again replaced i.e. this is the
total number of trees which have been purchased and planted, not the total
number of new trees presently on the highway network.
2. How many highway trees have been planted in Sheffield since the 13th
of January 2023?
176 trees. (Figures correct at 11-9-2023). This number will increase
before the end of 2023 as our planting season commences in October.
3. British Standard - PART 1 (1992) defines seven ‘forms’ (types) of
‘Standard Trees’, as follows:
Half; Extra Light; Light; Standard; Selected; Heavy; Extra Heavy.
How many highway trees of each British Standard ‘form’ of ‘Standard Tree’
have been planted on Sheffield’s streets since the ‘Streets Ahead’ project
began in 2012?
We do not hold specific information on this, however, to the best of our
knowledge and officer recollections, all the trees that have ever been
ordered have been specified to be extra heavy standard in size as defined
in the above British Standard. There have been instances that despite Amey
having specified extra heavy standards, trees of a small category have
been supplied; we do not hold data on the number of times this has been
the case.
In recent years where nurseries have been unable to supply our requested
species at extra heavy standard size, we have sought the agreement of the
Sheffield Street Tree Partnership that we will plant a small sized tree in
order to fulfil our duty to replace a felled tree within the current
planting season. We do not hold specific data on the number of times this
has been the case.
4. How many of the highway trees of each British Standard ‘form’ of
‘Standard Tree’ that have been planted on Sheffield’s streets since
the ‘Streets Ahead’ project began are currently on Sheffield’s streets
and alive?
As per the note at point 3 above, we do not information to be able to
answer this.
5. Of the highway trees planted in Sheffield since the start of the
‘Streets Ahead’ project, in 2012, how many were lifted in to position
on Sheffield’s streets using lifting machinery, such as a crane?
We do not hold this information.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.

If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you

https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.

Sheffield City Council

Sheffield, S1 1UJ
